metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 254 to 256 of 1958; Petitions Nos. 15 and 66 of 1957

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1958 was a taluqdar owning several taluqdari villages in Dholka Taluka of Ahmedabad District.
In 1922-23, revision settlement of land revenue fixed aggregate for taluqdari villages at Rs. 62,627-2-6.
In 1925-26, under s.22 Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888, Government declared jama of Rs. 32,643-3-0 payable, fixed for 30 years from 1925-26.
Bombay Taluqdari Abolition Act, 1949 passed in 1949, came into force on or about August 15, 1950. Taluqdari tenure abolished; appellant became occupant.
After expiry of 30-year period (1955-56), talatis demanded full land revenue assessment.
Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 255 of 1958 was taluqdar owning villages in Dholka and Dhandhuka Talukas; jama Rs. 5,734 vs settlement Rs. 14,452-11-0.
Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 256 of 1958 was taluqdar owning villages in Dholka Taluka; jama Rs. 21,877 vs settlement Rs. 44,551.
Writ Petition No. 66 of 1957 by appellant in CA 254 relates to Sanad estate; jama Rs. 20,886 vs settlement Rs. 48,247-13-0; demand for 1956-57.
Writ Petition No. 18 of 1957 by Thakur Vikramsinhji Manharsinhji of Gumph Estate (7 villages); jama Rs. 16,499-4-0 vs assessment Rs. 30,223-12-0; demand 1955-56.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Bombay High Court for prohibition against enhanced revenue for 1955-56; dismissed on May 14, 1956 and June 15, 1956.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court; writ petitions under Art. 32 heard together.

legal_issues.text: Whether after expiry of 30-year jama declaration under s.22 Taluqdars Act and abolition of taluqdari tenure, appellants liable only to pay jama till revision settlement under s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code, or full land revenue assessment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jama ascertained and declared for 30 years was fixed at the revenue settlement; by s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code, liable to pay only that till re-settlement.

respondent_arguments.text: Essential distinction between revenue settlement and ascertainment/declaration of jama under Taluqdars Act; after Abolition Act, jama payable only till 30-year expiry; thereafter as occupants, liable for entire land revenue assessment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888; Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949

court_reasoning.text: Taluqdars Act enabled survey under Code; s.22 fixed jama as aggregate survey assessments minus deductions, for up to 30 years. Abolition Act abolished tenure, made taluqdars occupants liable under Code; s.5(2)(b) saved jama declaration only so long as in force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jama declaration not a 'settlement of land revenue' under s.117R Code, which requires operations under Ch.VIII-A for groups/classes of land.

court_reasoning.text: Settlement under Code fixes revenue per survey number based on groups/factors; Taluqdars Act settlement registers had area/assessment per number, but jama under s.22 was aggregate minus deductions, distinct from land revenue assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jama payable distinct from revenue assessment of lands; s.117R applies to settlements, not jama declarations/agreements.

court_reasoning.text: Abolition Act s.17 saved declarations; s.5(2)(b) preserved jama till expiry. Post-expiry (1955-56), liable for full revenue per settlement registers under Code.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme: tenure abolished, occupants pay per Code unless saved jama in force.

holdings.text: Declaration under s.22 Taluqdars Act expired in 1955-56; appellants liable to pay entire land-revenue according to settlement registers from 1955-56.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined jama; enabled survey/settlement; fixed jama as aggregate assessments minus deductions for up to 30 years; saved prior agreements.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished taluqdari tenure; made taluqdars occupants liable under Land Revenue Code; saved jama declarations till expiry; repealed Taluqdars Act without affecting declarations.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs land revenue settlements (continue till revision); taluqdari lands liable per Code post-abolition; distinction from jama.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by special leave and writ petitions, upholding Bombay High Court; held appellants liable for full land revenue from 1955-56 after jama period expired.

key_quotes.text: "We, therefore hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding resolving the dispute in favor of respondents.

key_quotes.text: "the jama payable by the taluqdar was distinct from the revenue assessment of the land comprised in the taluqdari estate and they could not be equated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction rejecting petitioners' equation of jama with settlement under s.117R.
